conclusion: To find the effective value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, we need to follow these steps.
The magnetic flux Φ through the coil is given by Φ = B ⋅ A ⋅ cos(θ).
B is the magnetic field strength, A is the area of the coil, θ is the angle between the magnetic field and the normal to the coil.
Since the coil is rotating with angular velocity ω, the angle θ changes with time t as θ = ωt.
The area A of the square coil is A = L^2.
The magnetic flux as a function of time is Φ(t) = B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ cos(ωt).
The induced EMF 𝓔 is given by Faraday's law of induction: 𝓔 = -N dΦ/dt.
Taking the derivative of Φ(t) with respect to time gives dΦ/dt = -B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ ω ⋅ sin(ωt).
The induced EMF is 𝓔(t) = N ⋅ B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ ω ⋅ sin(ωt).
The effective value (RMS value) of the induced EMF is given by 𝓔_rms = 𝓔_max/√2.
The maximum value of 𝓔(t) occurs when sin(ωt) = 1, so 𝓔_max = N ⋅ B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ ω.
The effective value of the induced EMF is 𝓔_rms = N ⋅ B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ ω/√2.
The effective value of the induced electromotive force in the coil is 𝓔_rms = N ⋅ B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ ω/√2.
